title: Opening and 10 years award presentation

organizer: Abraham Bernstein, Department of Informatics, University of Zurich
Carole Goble, School of Mathematics, University of Manchester

segmentation: Good morning everybody.
Thank you.
In the tradition from last year, welcome to the 1st 13th International Semantic Web Conference.
I hope you're all following us on Twitter.
We already have over 400 followers, but we want to have more.
I'm Carol Goebel or I'm your general chair and this is our introduction to the actual main body of the conference.
We've already had some exciting events.
So I want to be able to start by thanking many people.
There are a whole bunch of people who put the show on the road, so as I said, I'm the general chair.
Yaron Lucarno, the organ local organizing jazz, and they've been absolutely fantastic as their team has been who put up the website and have been doing all the publicity and peep.
Who couldn't be with us who've done the metadata and have also produced the proceedings.
And of course our fantastic helpers in really tasteful pink shirts, the machismo amongst them will recover their their match owners later, but they look great.
I want to also thank all the sponsors.

This time we had 32 sponsors which is really a significant increase in in previous years and so This is why we're able to offer continuous cappuccino and espresso your own body weight in cakes at the brakes.
And of course yesterday is splendid.
Opening Para Teaff in with the with the choir.
So there's the sponsorship chairs.
Did a fantastic job and we're really, really thrilled about that.
The conference is no longer just a single conference, it's a whole bunch of things.
It's a focus for a whole bunch of located Co located events.
We already had the link top challenge several projects Co located with us for their meetings.
Ouled returned to the fold of the Semantic Web Conference and held their their meeting, and tonight we have the town Hall of a newly established European Ontology network.
That I hope you will be able to come along and support.
So some fun facts.
We have 630 delegates currently registered and more coming on board.
But that's a really good number.
We have over 300 presentations to come and we have 40 two countries represented by our members.
We also had eight tutorials and 22 workshops already happened in the last two days, and Johanna and Laura did a great job organizing those tutorials and workshops.
This year we ran a developers workshop for the first time.

I was Ruben and Eric from the eye mind slab, organized 70 people, attended the Developers Workshop, which is really impressive and you really could just see lines of code on the screen and everybody was terribly excited about that, so that's great.
And we have a semantic Web developer of the year which we awarded a prize that he'll never be able to get through customs in his carry-on because it's actually a weapon on a stick.
I realized afterwards, but we have a semantic Web developer of the year which is who is Ken till kids gender SMO.
I'm sorry, I've just mangled your name horribly, but there you are.
But can we just say?
Gratulation's again to our first prize winner.
So our students are represented significantly in this conference.

We have 172 students here plus the student volunteers, and Natasha and Paul organized a fantastic doctoral consortium and Oscar Merriam, running the mentoring lunch and also administered 30 travel awards from this was a foundation that runs this conferences conference series, and we also had generous sponsorship from the National Science Foundation.
Who also sponsored American students.

We have some special sessions lightning talks which Alistair Gray is kindly stepped in to organize that will be running on Thursday in the morning and you submit through easy chair in the previous conference.
The last conference where we had lightning talks, there weren't so many lightning talks and we were little bit nervous about that.
However, we've had quite a few already, so we've had 20 submissions already before the conference started, so we're going to close the submission to easy chair.
For applications to speak at the Lightning talk early.
So Wednesday lunchtime.
So gives us some time to sort through them because it's been so popular.
We also have the Semantic Web challenge which has also its posters and demos at the same time as the rest of the posters and demos session.
And they'll be a judging panel who will be choosing the Semantic Web challenge.
So come along to those sessions.
The Pope.
String Demo Madness is this afternoon or this evening.
We have 71 posters and 50 demos, so we're going to have the minute Magnes later on and the minute manage will be intense.
Really on off it'll be time slides and you can vote for the best poster and demo by the IS which app and on the website using the Mystery Anonymous number in your bag.
If you've thrown away the Mystery anonymous number.
In your bag we can supply new ones.
There will also be linked up posters and demos as well from the link top Track.
So the voting if you if you go to the website.
Oh, as I've got up here, you'll be able to navigate the website to do online voting.
If you use the app then you go to browse followed by filter followed by poster followed by select.
I hope you've all written down that Breadcrumb Trail so thank you to CNR for providing the app and you just just search for eswick live for the for the app.
The industry track is on Wednesday.
We have 7 long talks, 1 keynote and 20 of these push cuccia.
I'm rubbish at saying names I can't even say my own name for goodness sake.
Talks and these are very fast talks.
These 20 slides and each slide is 20 seconds, so it's going to be interesting.
Back to the main kind of core of the of the conference, which is the peer reviewed papers.
So we have research track in use track and replication benchmark data and software track also the really blinking data are difficult services or or source track.
So we had a lot of submissions.
Research track had 180.
We had 21% acceptance rate, the news track and also the replication track.
This year was an experiment and I think it was a successful experiment and so they'll be a version of it in the follow up following years.
And thank you to all chairs for really organizing a fantastic job on the paper.
This despite the best efforts of Easychair to ruin our lives, so some of you will remember that easy chair moved to a new server on the very day of the paper submissions for these tracks.
Luckily, I work in the same Department as the founder of Easy Chair, so I was able to re educate him.
Urgently so.
Will bear that in mind for next year.
So we haven't made a few wordles for the different track to see the kind of these are the papers titles of the papers they were accepted.
So in the research track we see ontology very strong.
Still, RDF sparkle query all the technologies in order to be able to handle knowledge and data.
The in use track data is the big one.
In replication benchmark data is the big one and.
This is all data is the big one with links, so I think we can see a data theme emerging through our conference.
All these slides will be available for you to analyze in detail later.
So I finally would say a few thank yous to the 292 slots on the program committees.
The senior program committees and the additional reviewers.
This is a fantastic effort from all of our organizers and under the people participated or the people who submitted papers.
In fact, we really wanted to reward the reviewers and people who participate on those committees.
And so we have a best reviewers prize to winners for the research track, Burt and Anton, and two in the in use track, Fabian and Kristoff, and they will have a certificate and award.
Sadly, they did all this fantastic work and these reviews were voted by the recipients of the reviewers as well as the track chairs, and they were primarily Interestingly for negative reviews.
So this is people who really.

Appreciated detailed reviews and these people did outstanding reviews of length and consistently across all of their papers, but none of them could make the conference so, so that's a pity, but we will we honor them Despite that so.
X.
So there are a whole bunch of best papers I won't go into too details because you can't read them fast enough, but they're all in your splendid booklet.
They're all marked up, so we have some Tuesday morning this morning and tomorrow morning in the research track for the best papers there.
We
We also have the best student papers in the research track this afternoon, Wednesday afternoon and Thursday morning.
Please look in your pack and look in your look on line at the list of papers.
Look in the book.
Right and the same for the in you strike Tuesday afternoon and Wednesday morning.
And in fact two of them were in the same session, so you get a double whammy if you go to the.
Session.
Speakers and chairs please be at your sessions during the break to check technicalities and procedures.
Because we're allowing everybody to use their own laptop.
So finally, thank you.
Thank you to everyone who submitted a paper.
Everyone is presenting a paper.
Everyone who organized something, everybody who ran a workshop and everybody for coming because it would be a bit Daft if we did all this work and there wasn't anybody here.
So I really appreciate all of you coming and have a fantastic workshop and conference and social events later on.
So now we turn to.
Abby Bernstein, who's going to introduce the 10 year award?
Well, ladies and gentlemen, it's a pleasure to be here.
I am the Vice president of Swizzor, together with Ian works with as the organization or the steering committee for this conference.
Mostly we pour over highly interesting budgets to decide where the next conference is, but we have one activity.
Apart from picking such wonderful people as Carol to run the conference, and Karen Luciano one activity that is a joy every year.
Which is we get to put together a committee to pick.
The 10 year awards.
The way this works is we look at the top papers and then put together a committee.

That gets assembled from people from the conference organizations, such as general chairs and program chairs, as well as people from Swisa itself who do not have a conflict of interest with any of the papers in the top.
So this year it was Peter, Ian Carroll and myself.
We looked at the top side of papers and usually what we do then is we look through these papers and make sure they don't get cited for.
This was a really bad paper.

And this year I have to say it was very, very clear this year's award goes to a paper that presented a piece of software that probably everybody in this room installed on their computer at one point or another in some incarnation.
This year's swiza 10 Years award goes to hold.
New blouse Ray Ferguson.
Natalia Friedman oil and Mark Musen for the protege Al Plug in an open development environment for semantic web applications.
Why don't you come up?
Congratulations.
You need to come up.
There was going to be the official.
They get a certificate and money.
This being Europe, we transfer the money through electronic transfers such that the NSA can keep tabs on it.
Let me do this in order in order of authorship, right?
Gratulation Yep Yep.
No, I did get it wrong, sorry.
Congratulations Mark, congratulations, thank you very much.
And what is splendid job?
Thank you.
Now.
At this point, most of us disappear, but Mark stays here and he actually is going to tell us something about the Protege Owl plug-in.
Thank you Mark ticket from here, OK?
